column4: Can anyone recommend WYSIWYG page layout software that can visibly arrange text across multiple pages that will be trimmed?  For making banners and such.  I know a lot of graphics programs can "just do" that sort of printing, but I want to see where the page breaks will be while editing.  InDesign can almost do it.  Scribus apparently can't.
if you're adventurous, you could try LaTeX
oh wait, not wisywig
latex would still rely on something that can print it properly.  and the wysiwyg problem
well, I'm assuming you would have a printer, since you obviously need one for a banner
i meant software
i could live with latex + [something that can print preview it] , if that was the only option
you can use pdflatex to generate pdfs, and you can preview pdfs with evince or Adobe reader
ok, ill keep that in mind as a last resort
I suppose you've already tried inkscape?
i have.  its one of the programs that will "just do" it without showing me where  :(
can't you just define the pages as being, say, 1 inch smaller than the real pages, and then get the printer to print them centered on the page?
im not sure how to define fake page sizes in any of the programs
except inkscape, but its lacking elsewhere
take scribus for example: new>>page size>>custom
ill give that a try, thanks.
in scribus, how do i define a multi-page document with pages in a grid instead of sequential?
you mean it has to be a 2 dimensional array of pages??
im going to, for instance, wallpaper my room with letter sized sheets of paper, and i want to print them all from a single huge document.
wow, that's a unique project
i hear that a lot :-p
ok, I think you should just buy a bigger printer
